pr_title: [RW-4445][risk=low] Add OpsGenieService to create alerts on inbound high-egress events.

timeline.message: Add OpsGenieService to create alerts on inbound high-egress events.

timeline.bodyText: I was a little surprised that we didn't have this in our backend config already. I think it's distinct enough from the API base URL (they're different App Engine services with different base paths) that it's worth including here. I'm open to alternative suggestions, though.
timeline.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: It still seems odd for this to be named SumoLogicController, since it doesn't directly depend on or control SumoLogic at all. Maybe EgressEventController?
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I added some class-level comments addressing this. This controller is an inbound API that is very much tied to SumoLogic's data export structure, so it is absolutely Sumo-specific.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: nit: it might help to organize all the file names in this bucket into a CedentialFile enum so you can ensure that you don't accidentally reuse one. I guess the bigger benefit is containing all these strings into one class that knows what to do with them.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I'll punt on this, it might be a nice cleanup though – filed https://precisionmedicineinitiative.atlassian.net/browse/RW-4661 to track.

timeline.bodyText: TOL: I think it would be good to have a policy here for what kinds of changes should be dynamic vs requiring a restart. I agree that a credential rotation shouldn't require a restart.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText: Not your fault, but this is a pretty awkward way to set up the constructor/builder.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

timeline.bodyText:
One thing to think about would be making one service for sending things to OpsGenie (that traffics in that libraries objects, like CreateAlertRequest), and a slightly higher-level service for handling egress events (that, among possibly other things, would make one of those requests and call the OpsGenieService to send it).
In other words, even though this is small and readable, there's a minor smell I think in OpsGenieServiceImpl, because it knows about a workbench-specific concept (i.e. the EgressEvent).
There are potentially some testing advantages to this split as well (such as mocking the lower service), and we can add another alert trigger later with less tear-up. Though I realize you don't want this to become a pattern.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText:
I'm treating the OpsGenie client as the lower-level library that we're trusting is well-tested enough to use for our higher-level needs (and which is mocked out in unit tests).
And since we're talking about ~dozens of lines of code here, I'm not too worried about not having the perfect / optimal structure. This can be easily changed as our needs shift over time.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: With the void return here, you won't be able to distinguish easily which Egress Alert maps to which OG alert if there are many happening at once. I'd try to provide bi-directional traceability if possible.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I'm not sure quite what you're getting at. Traceability from where to where? I'm not sure this would be needed, or I'd at least like to validate the need / requirement in practice before potentially over-building here.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: You don't strictly need this yet, but I'm a bit surprised there's no cancelAlert endpoint here. For testing, etc, it would be nice to have a button or script to kill the alert after it's created. Plus, we could be sure that we have a good handle on the alert we've created with the create API.
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText:
It would be a YAGNI smell – for now, there is no active flow where the Workbench should close a high-egress alert. It can only open a new alert or add a note to an existing alert.
I could imagine such a thing being useful for an end-to-end test of the high-egress alerting functionality; it will be trivial to add at that point.
replies.author: gjuggler

timeline.bodyText: Can we also fetch information about the user like username, email, and institution?
timeline.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText: I considered this, but it turns out programmatically looking up the username / email / etc is a bit more complicated (effectively, we'd have to extract this method body into a central service of some sort). I'm not sure the value is huge, since that info is presented directly in the workspace admin landing page which is the clear alert call-to-action.
replies.author: gjuggler

replies.bodyText:
OK. Can we link directly to that page in the description?
From a belt-and-suspenders standpoint, there's a slight chance that the person receiving the alert won't be able to get to the admin console or that it isn't working for some reason. So it would still be spiffy to have that info in the alert. Likewise, if you've got a stack of closed egress alerts, it would be easier to flip through them afterwards without leaving OpsGenie.
That could be follow-on work though.
replies.author: jaycarlton

replies.bodyText:
Yep – I don't disagree it will be nice, but I wanted to hold off from getting too fancy so we have at least something running in prod to start working with.
And see 2 lines below this, we do have a direct link to the admin page.
